results.title: The Magic Trumpet
results.creator_credit: Dusan Marek, Anim-ad Films and Eltham Films
results.brief_description: An experimental film using mainly animated paper cut-outs to tell the story of a magic trumpet which brings fame and fortune to an old tramp. Story script by Tim Burstall, music by Michael Kenny and montage, animation and photography by Dusan Marek.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Dusan Marek, Anim-ad Films and Eltham Films

results.title: [George Robinson Parsons Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
The George Robinson Parsons Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 16mm AGFA film. George Robinson (Robin) Parsons was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies on a Bolex camera during the period 1929 to 1938. The home movies show life in Melbourne and regional Victoria in the 1930s.

This film shows an example of life in Victoria, Australia, just prior to the Second World War. Much of it revolves around members of the Parsons family and friends who are clearly not camera shy. In a number of scenes, you can see individuals playing up to the camera. There is even a staged boxing match on the beach where Robin (George Robinson) Parsons experimented with using special effects.

The film shows several Victorian locations including Melbourne, Dromana, Rosebud Aerodrome, Cape Schanck, Mt Hotham, Mallacoota, Wangarrata and Yallourn. Dromana Beach is featured a few times and appears to be a family favourite for swimming and family gatherings.

This film is rich with fashion of the period, both casual and formal, including two weddings of different periods and golfing attire.

Included in the film is the 1935 centennial celebrations parade showing crowded street with brass bands travelling down Collins Street, including a brief scene of an Aboriginal float. Much of these scenes are taken from the rooftop of Parsons Bros and company building. The company would later form Uncle Toby’s.

The film also includes the Shrine of Remembrance, St Pauls cathedral, Princes Bridge and many other Melbourne landmarks including some buildings and sites that no longer exist.

Of interest are the many forms of transport that are seen throughout which include cars, trams, horses, bicycles, motor bike with side carriage, a canoe, bi planes, fighter planes, a gyrocopter, the Saro A17 Cutty Sark seaplane (only 12 were ever created), transport planes, steamboats, tugboats, a navy ship, locomotives and a Melbourne ferry.

Also of interest is a scene from the 1939 Australian Championship at Kooyong Stadium with John Bromwich and Adrian Quist.

Selected Highlights List
00:00:02:00 – Geoffrey and Jean Parsons playing with a Fox Terrier
00:01:12:00 – Wedding of Mary Dowling Woods and John Bedggood
00:02:07:00 – Melbourne Grammar Sports day at the MCG
00:03:52:00 – The Rose family, Aeneas Gunn and Robin Parsons at the Rose family home with dogs
00:05:10:00 – Doug Rose and Aeneas Gunn riding a cow
00:07:34:00 – Steam boat on the Yarra River
00:07:48:00 – Parson family and friends swimming at Dromana beach showing 1930’s swimming costumes
00:08:44:00 Sidney and Susannah Parsons at Dromana Beach
00:09:53:00 – Parsons family doing Acrobats, playing games and making a human tower at Dromana Beach
00:10:55:00 – Bi Planes – VH–UHR, VH-UHS and VH-UAT
00:12:23:00 – Two women and Geoffrey Parsons on a rug in the garden of the family home
00:14:01:00 – Susannah Parsons demonstrating her golfing swing
00:14:52:00 – View of Princes bridge with Flinders Street Railway station in the Background
00:15:20:00 – View towards the Flinders street Fish Market (demolished in 1956)
00:15:26:00 – Steam boats docked on the Yarra river.
00:15:46:00 – Navy ship in the harbour
00:16:06:00 – The shrine of Remembrance (before the gardens were there) and views of Melbourne from its balcony.
00:21:28:00 – View of Collins Street from the roof of the Parson Bros Mill near Spencer street station, showing the 1935 centennial celebrations parade
00:22:45:00 – Sidney Parsons, Robin Parsons and unknown man playing golf
00:23:56:00 - View from the rooftop of Parsons Bros Mill on Collins Street looking up towards the Victorian Railway administration offices on Spencer street and down Flinders Lane.
00:24:20:00 – People lining Nicholson street (near parliament gardens) to watch lavish floats and masked performers.
00:30:56:00 – Parson family members at the beach in Dromana
00:37:24:00 – Doug and Charlie Parsons climbing the sign labelled the highest house in Australia at Hotham Heights and camping trip
00:42:30:00 – Front view of motorbike with side car following on the road in wet weather
00:27:23:00 – Parson brothers, friends and fiancée Jean, on the coast of Cape Shanck.
00:42:59:00 – Jean Parsons (portrait view)
00:43:03:00 – Robin Parsons (portrait view) smoking
00:43:18:00 – 1939 Australian Championship, Kooyong Stadium – John Bromwich and Adrian Quist
00:43:56:00 – Wedding of unknown couple
00:44:42:00 – VH-USQ Cierva C.30A Auto gyro (Gyrocopter)
00:46:37:00 – The Saro A17 Cutty Sark seaplane off Dromana Beach. Geoffrey Parsons climbing out of the Cockpit. (VH-UNV)
00:47:51:00 – Douglas DC-2 Airliner VH-USY “Bungana” outside Holymans hangar at Melbourne/Essendon airport
00:48:24:00 – Miles M-3 Merlin (VH-UXN) (Came to Australia in 1936)
00:48:41:00 – De Havilland D.H. 86A express (VH-UUB) Loila outside Holymans Hanger at Melbourne Essendon airport
00:53:23:00 – Rifle shooting in the snow at Mount Hotham

results.title: [Kirsty Sword Gusmao Film Collection: Reel 3]
results.brief_description:
Titled The Stars Were. This film shows closeups of the children who starred in “Walking to School” and “The Bear”.

The film then moves on to show a tractor dragging flames to set fire to a dry paddock. We see various farm scenery including sheep, burning off, horse riding and a tractor ploughing a field.

The film then shows a narrative short story titled “The Wish Wizard” which could be an Eaglehawk Primary school production. This film shows school children discovering a book which contains a map to “The Olde Wishing Well”. They gather together and conjure up a wizard using a magic spell. We see good close ups of children’s faces as they interact with the wizard.

We then see a school boy walking and running down a country road where he discovers animal tracks in the dirt and encounters a woman wearing a red coat carrying apples in a basket.

This film shows good examples of school fashion, children’s faces and farming practices.

Selected highlights (timecodes from Access Overscan)
00:00:49:00 - Title card Story ‘The Bear’
00:01:05:00 - Burning off with tractor
00:02:56:00 - Title card ‘the wish wizard’

results.title: [Kirsty Sword Gusmao Film Collection: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
This film shows a slice of life from a working dairy farm in central Gippsland, Victoria.

We see cows being milked, the milk cans being loaded onto trucks and in to the trays of utility cars. The milk is transported by road to the Maffra Co-operative Milk Products Company.

There are scenes of hay bales being driven around the paddocks in the back of a ute. The hay is divided in to sections and fed to the cattle. We see de-horned Jersey and Friesian cows and bulls eating the hay and children riding a WX 572 tractor.

There is footage of a newly born calf being licked clean by its mother and we see the calf’s first attempt to stand and take its first steps.

The film also shows a family visit to the Glenmaggie Dam Enlargement Project Observation Point.

Selected sequence list (timecodes from Access Overscan)
00:00:54:00 The Maffra Co-operative Milk Products Co LTD sign
00:02:12:00 Title card ‘A Calf is Born’
00:03:55:00 Dad and kids riding a tractor
00:04:00:00 Title card ‘Wattle Time’
00:04:38:00 Glenmaggie Dam Enlargement Project Observation Point

results.title: Women breakout
results.creator_credit: Erika Addis and Halfway House Collective
results.brief_description: This film was made by the Halfway House Collective in Melbourne and is set in Halfway House a feminist refuge. The film does not so much focus on the circumstances that led them to the Halfway House, rather it shows the house giving them support to take control of and change their lives.

results.title: [Len Moncur Home Movies: Reel 5]
results.brief_description:
The Len Moncur Home Movie Collection is a collection of amateur films made on 8mm film in the 1950s and 1960s.

This animated film, titled ‘Storm at the 20th’, is a comedy about a group of beleaguered golf ball people, often wearing golf tee hats and with pipe cleaner limbs, who come together to protest against injury from golfers. They decide to take evasive action including using feathers to fly out of the way of golf sticks and a self-destructing do-it-yourself glider kit.

There are details such as the terrible injuries inflicted by golfers and one of the organisers drinking non-stop from what looks like a whiskey bottle.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:07:00 title cards ‘Storm at the 20th’ and ‘Animation by Len Moncur’
00:00:10:00 golf ball people are rushing around a busy street
00:00:18:00 a sign ‘Protest Meeting - Every Brand - Even repaints – Something must be done!’
00:00:26:00 sign ‘Trades Hall 20th Hole Branch’
00:00:29:00 wonderful miniature and detailed vehicles pass by including a tram from which many golf ball people alight
00:00:38:00 close-up of ‘Before it happens towing service’ tow truck
00:00:43:00 golf ball mechanics fix a broken down vehicle
00:00:50:00 an injured golf ball mechanic is taken away by stretcher and ambulance
00:01:16:00 the protest meeting proceeds with the manifesto stating that golf ball people are being treated badly by golfers
00:01:25:00 one of the organisers drinking strong spirits followed by several examples of gruesome golf ball injuries
00:02:35:00 baby golf ball people in a bassinette
00:02:48:00 the golf ball people learn evasive tactics on the golf course
00:04:33:00 boxes labelled ‘Do it yourself Glider Kit’ followed by a demonstration of how the glider assists the golf ball person avoid being hit by a golfer by flying through the air and then self-destructing once the golf ball person shields in a bush
00:05:09:00 the golf ball people squash into their sporty car and after travelling down the road, pop themselves into their boxes
00:05:24:00 title ‘The End’
results.description:
This animated film, titled Storm at the 20th, is a comedy about a group of beleaguered golf ball people, often wearing golf tee hats and with pipe cleaner limbs, who come together to protest against injury from golfers. They decide to take evasive action including using feathers to fly out of the way of golf sticks and a self-destructing do-it-yourself glider kit.

There are details such as the terrible injuries inflicted by golfers and one of the organisers drinking non-stop from what looks like a whiskey bottle.

Selected highlights list:

00:00:07:00 title cards ‘Storm at the 20th’ and ‘Animation by Len Moncur’

00:00:10:00 golf ball people are rushing around a busy street

00:00:18:00 a sign ‘Protest Meeting - Every Brand - Even repaints – Something must be done!’

00:00:26:00 sign ‘Trades Hall 20th Hole Branch’

00:00:29:00 wonderful miniature and detailed vehicles pass by including a tram from which many golf ball people alight

00:00:38:00 close-up of ‘Before it happens towing service’ tow truck

00:00:43:00 golf ball mechanics fix a broken down vehicle

00:00:50:00 an injured golf ball mechanic is taken away by stretcher and ambulance

00:01:16:00 the protest meeting proceeds with the manifesto stating that golf ball people are being treated badly by golfers

00:01:25:00 one of the organisers drinking strong spirits followed by several examples of gruesome golf ball injuries

00:02:35:00 baby golf ball people in a bassinette

00:02:48:00 the golf ball people learn evasive tactics on the golf course

00:04:33:00 boxes labelled ‘Do it yourself Glider Kit’ followed by a demonstration of how the glider assists the golf ball person avoid being hit by a golfer by flying through the air and then self-destructing once the golf ball person shields in a bush

00:05:09:00 the golf ball people squash into their sporty car and after travelling down the road, pop themselves into their boxes

00:05:24:00 title ‘The End’

results.title: A Wilted Flower
results.brief_description: Winner in the Middle Live Action category. In a student-made, psychological and mental-health themed short film, a girl, followed by the dark side and thoughts of herself must overcome a presence in her life, or fail and succumb to it. A dark cloud can wilt any flower, but can this flower find the light again?

results.title: The Shackles You Cannot See
results.creator_credit: Robyn Fairbairn and St Mary's Anglican Girls' College
results.brief_description: Special Mention in the Senior Live Action category. The premise of The Shackles You Cannot See is to explore the blurred lines between Fate vs. Free Will in the Modern World. As a futuristic dystopian narrative, it stands as a warning of the consequences of technological advances, to make people question their actions in their daily life, as well as question their rights to psychological and physical freedom.

results.title: The Professor
results.brief_description: A Special Mention in the Middle Live Action category. Set in the 1900’s, there has been a series of unsolved murders. Two professors have been put on the case. Unfortunately for one he doesn’t know who his partner is until it’s too late.
